titleInfo.title: Efficient Learning of the State in Dynamic Systems from Model-Based to Data-Based

name.namePart: Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering

mods:mods.abstract: Understanding and predicting states in dynamic systems is a core challenge in many areas of study. This involves trying to estimate an evolving signal based on past observations or the understood rules of the system. Main obstacles include errors in observations, the unknowns, and the complexity of these rules. This dissertation delves into the challenge of state estimation in dynamic systems, especially in scenarios with limited information at hand. Central to our exploration is striking a balance between the volume of available data and the precision of our state predictions. Broadly, our sources of information fall into two camps: measurements, which are historical observations, and models, the theoretical frameworks defining system evolution. While dense and precise measurements are desirable for accuracy, they are often constrained by technological limitations. On the flip side, while detailed models can guide precise predictions, they are sometimes elusive for complex systems. Initially, the research delves into model-based estimation, where system models are employed to calculate system states. However, uncertainties in various factors, such as initial conditions or the model itself, introduce errors. A unique scenario within model-based estimation is explored where humans function as sensors in a cyber-physical-human system, sending binary signals based on system performance, shedding light on the challenges of relying on such sparse information. // The research then shifts to data-based estimation in scenarios where system models are undefined or unknown. The primary challenge here is predicting system states with scarce data and minimal understanding of the system's dynamics. Two significant techniques, physics-informed neural networks (PINN) and deep operator networks (DeepONet), are investigated to approach this problem. The proposed method attempts to combine the strengths of both techniques and also integrate findings from prior research on short-term dependencies in systems. The methodology follows two phases: understanding system dynamics and refining estimations to address error accumulations. The former aims to identify key influences of the current state using historical data. The efficacy of this method is demonstrated using the ultra-high magnetic response system as a case study. The latter phase reduces error accumulation by directly mapping initial states and inputs to current states, using a unique DeepONet framework that incorporates findings from short-term dependencies.// This dissertation offers novel insights into the challenges and solutions for state estimation in dynamic systems with limited information. The presented methods and findings have broad implications for fields reliant on accurate state estimations.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Lichun Li, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jonathan Clark, University Representative; Omer Arda Vanli, Committee Member; Chiwoo Park, Committee Member.
